ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about German culture, grammar, different greeting phases, and films.
Developed my German reading, writing, and speaking skills further. In addition, it was crucial to immerse oneself in the context of German history, modernity, and society.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor was a big strength, but sometimes is was difficult to know what we needed to know in terms of studying for the tests
Shila did her best to include each student in class conversations and discussions, which was among the most significant strengths. As both a student and a teacher, I believe this course had no flaws.

The main weakness of this course is the formulation of the final project. I felt like it did little to test and/or utilize the skills wed developed over the semester. 

Otherwise, this course was very strong.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this to another student if they want to continue learning about German culture and grammar.

Yes, and primarily because of Shila's teaching style.

However, there were organizational inadequacies onthe part ofGerman Department. I continue to be baffled by the requirement to purchase expensive textbooks and supplements, while students inother language coursespay almost nothing for course materials. I also do not comprehend why students must purchase two-year subscriptions to applicationscontaining learning materials (Kontakte) that become useless after one year of use? It appears to me that the administration of the German Department treats students and course organization with their sleeves down and thinking only of their own interests, ignoring the interests of students, especially graduate students.
